citation.article-title: A new species of soil bacteria of the genus Prosthecomicrobium.

p.s: Description of Prosthecomicrobium consociatum sp. nov.
Prosthecomicrobium consociatum (con.so.cia.tum - the Latin name meaning growth in a community with cellulose degrading bacteria)
The cells are short thick rods, 0.5-1.0 μm in diameter and 0.8-1.35 μm long, single or in pairs.
Stationary (nonmotile) prosthecae are closely located in five rows along the cell.
The prosthecae size is 0.20-0.25 μm.
They have the following distinctive feature; 5 rows of prosthecae as a five-pointed star are well seen along the cell axis.
They reproduce by budding, prosthecae in the daughter cell are located at an angle to mother cell.
The cells are aerobes, catalase and oxidase positive.
Colonies are gray, rounded, prominent, of a thick consistency, up to 1 mm in diameter.
The organism is a chemoorganotroph utilizing some monosaccharides as a sole source of carbon and energy (Tables 2 and 3).
Di-, tri-, polysaccharides and amino acids are not utilized (except for lactose by strain II).
Several sugar alcohols, organic acids of the Krebs cycle, methanol and monomethylamine can be utilized.
Yeast extract or vitamins of the B group are required for bacterial growth.
Hydrolytic activity is absent.
The optimal growth temperature is 28-30°C, pH-neutral.
The organism is extremely sensitive to penicillin.
MPK from 0.09 to 0.7 μg/ml [6].
The bacterium is widespread in soils and composts where the degradation of organic material is rapid.
The organism has been isolated from compost.
It is present in the communities of cellulose degrading bacteria.
The GC-content of DNA is about 66.0-68.5 mol% (as determined by heat denaturation).
The typical strain 11 has been deposited with the Institute of Microbiology, the USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, USSR.
